critique: This executive order aims to prevent discrimination in federally conducted education and training programs. It covers a wide range of protected characteristics, including race, sex, color, national origin, disability, religion, age, sexual orientation, and status as a parent. It also establishes administrative enforcement mechanisms and reporting requirements. However, it includes exemptions for the armed forces, military education programs, and certain affirmative action plans. It also does not create any new judicially reviewable rights. The order seems to expand federal oversight and intervention in education and training programs to ensure non-discrimination. It also centralizes power in the Attorney General's office to create rules and regulations. It also emphasizes diversity and inclusion. It does not seem to touch on immigration. It also does not seem to expand executive power significantly, as it is mostly focused on implementing existing laws and regulations.
